items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences
items.body:
Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences. This can be fixed by using raw strings or escaping the literals. pyupgrade also helps in automatic conversion : https://github.com/asottile/pyupgrade/

```
find . -iname '*.py' | grep -Ev 'vendor|example|doc|tools|sphinx' | xargs -P4 -I{} python3.8 -Wall -m py_compile {}
./nbconvert/filters/tests/test_citation.py:33: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \c
  """:  """
./nbconvert/filters/tests/test_markdown.py:211: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \c
  """$m$
./nbconvert/filters/tests/test_markdown.py:219: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \o
  """$r=\overline{1,n}$
./nbconvert/exporters/tests/test_latex.py:118: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \d
  """
```

**Nbconvert version:** master

items.title: RegexRemovePreprocessor does not work with newlines
items.body:
<!--- Description --->
https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/blob/master/nbconvert/preprocessors/regexremove.py#L56 needs to take `re.MULTILINE` to match cell sources that have multiple lines in them

<!--- Can you list steps to reproduce this issue? --->
```
>>> import re
>>> m = re.compile('.*a.*')
>>> m.match('xxxaxxx\nxxxbxxx')
<re.Match object; span=(0, 7), match='xxxaxxx'>
>>> m.match('xxxbxxx\nxxxaxxx') # does not match!!!!
>>> m.match('xxxbxxx\nxxxaxxx', re.MULTILINE) # matches
<re.Match object; span=(8, 15), match='xxxaxxx'>
```

items.title: --EmbedImagesPreprocessor.embed_images=True does not embed images
items.body:
Hello, I am running nbconvert 5.6.1. I have a sample notebook (notebook.py), with 1 cell: ```python from IPython.core.display import HTML display(HTML('')) ``` I then run ```bash jupyter nbconvert --to html --EmbedImagesPreprocessor.embed_images=True \ notebook.ipynb ``` A notebook.html is created, but unfortunately the image is not embedded, I get on line 11769: ```html
``` That behaviour was different (i.e. it worked fine) on my previous environment (python 3.6 with pretty up to date nbconvert). Any ideas of how I can fix it? Thanks,

items.title: docx --TemplateExporter.exclude_input=True doesn't remove input cells
items.body:
<!--- Description --->
Creating a docx file from a notebook with the --TemplateExporter.exclude_input=True option doesn't remove input cells. It works as advertised for other output files (pdf, latex, html are the ones I tested).

Note, original post is here https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/5623

<!--- Can you list steps to reproduce this issue? --->
Steps to reproduce
```bash
jupyter nbconvert --to docx --TemplateExporter.exclude_input=True Untitled.ipynb  
```

<!--- Can you, if possible, please attach a minimum notebook that reproduces this issue on conversion?
You may need to attach the .ipynb as a .txt --->
[Untitled.ipynb](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/files/4958120/Untitled.txt)
[Untitled.docx](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/files/4958124/Untitled.docx)

An expected output in pdf format
[Untitled.pdf](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/files/4958125/Untitled.pdf)


<!--- Can you attach screenshots if relevant? --->

<!--- Are you running the latest version of nbconvert? --->
**Nbconvert version:**
5.6.1

items.body:

When i try the same via CLI i get the same message.

items.title: Proposal: restore executenb
items.body:
`nbconvert.preprocessors.execute.executenb` was removed in #1211. This will require downstream libraries that relied on this to adjust (here's my own example https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-sphinx/issues/139). At the same time this backwards compatibility breaking could be avoided, it seems, by a single line:

```python
from nbclient.client import execute as executenb`
```

Would this be acceptable?

items.title: where is custom.css in the generated html file from nbconvert
Inkscape doesn't accept "--without-gui" option anymore
items.body:
The inkscape command line options changed with the latest version:
[https://wiki.inkscape.org/wiki/index.php/Using_the_Command_Line](https://wiki.inkscape.org/wiki/index.php/Using_the_Command_Line)

The --without-gui and --export-pdf options are not recognized anymore and make the conversion fail.

items.title: Output to folder
items.body:
<!--- Is your feature request related to a problem? What are you trying to achieve? --->

If I have a directory structure as follows:
```

├── build
├── notebooks
│   └── demo_notebook.ipynb
```

I'd like to be able to, from the root directory, convert a notebook from `notebooks` to html and save it in `build`.

<!--- Describe the solution you'd like. --->

```
jupyter nbconvert notebooks/demo_notebook.ipynb --output build/
```

<!--- If possible, describe alternatives you've considered. Why are they insufficent? --->
I can currently achieve this with
```
jupyter nbconvert notebooks/demo_notebook.ipynb
mv notebooks/demo_notebook.html build/
```

----

Would a feature of this kind be welcome? Am happy to work on a pull request if so

items.body:
<!--- Is your feature request related to a problem? What are you trying to achieve? --->

<!--- Describe the solution you'd like. --->
A beautiful neat Github action

<!--- If possible, describe alternatives you've considered. Why are they insufficent? --->
I have tried the following

```
FROM jupyter as slides

COPY --chown=jovyan:100 ./work $WORK

RUN mkdir /home/$NB_USER/slides && \
    chown -R jovyan:100 /home/$NB_USER/slides

CMD jupyter nbconvert --output-dir=/home/$NB_USER/slides /home/$NB_USER/work/*.ipynb --to html

```

items.title: Running Jupyter Notebook with Different Configurations
items.body:
Hey everybody!

I started to use Jupyter Notebook for my project and I use `nbconvert` to run it from the command line.
I want to know that is there any way to have a `.ipynb` file and run it with some command-line arguments or reading from `stdin` somewhere?
I read `nbconvert` documentation but I didn’t find out a way to do it.

If there is no way to do something like those, I want to know what is the best practice to have a single `.ipynb` file and run it with different configurations?

Thank you in advance.

items.title: Can extra_arguments be made configurable in ExecutePreprocessor?
items.body:
In the `ExecutePreprocesor` class, the `extra_arguments` traitlet is not configurable (i.e. we cannot do `c.ExecutePreprocessor.extra_arguments = [commands here]`) because it is not defined with `.tag(config=True)`.

I'm guessing there is a reason for this.

I see that I can set it with the constructor `ExecutePreprocessor(extra_arguments=[commands here])`, but it seems like one of the only traitlets that's not configurable.

items.title: How am I supposed to use new template system?
items.body:
I have this:
```
class MyMdExporter(TemplateExporter):
    file_extension = ".md"
    template_file = "markdown/index.md.j2"
```

But it fails since in the file `index.md.j2`, there's an `{% extends display_priority.j2 %}` instead of `{% extends base/display_priority.j2 }%` (and also recursively, in `display_priority.j2`, the reference to `null.j2`}
```
jinja2.exceptions.TemplateNotFound: display_priority.j2
```

What I did is this:
```
diff --git a/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/base/display_priority.j2 b/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/base/display_priority.j2
index beaa196a..56ad7cde 100644
--- a/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/base/display_priority.j2
+++ b/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/base/display_priority.j2
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
-{%- extends 'null.j2' -%}
+{%- extends 'base/null.j2' -%}
 
 {#display data priority#}
 
diff --git a/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/markdown/index.md.j2 b/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/markdown/index.md.j2
index 8906eff8..f4421520 100644
--- a/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/markdown/index.md.j2
+++ b/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/markdown/index.md.j2
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
-{% extends 'display_priority.j2' %}
+{% extends 'base/display_priority.j2' %}
 
 
 {% block in_prompt %}
```

Is it correct? Or do I need to copy the `markdown/index.md.j2` into `compatibility/markdown.tpl`?

items.title: Import location for CellExecutionError has changed
items.body:
Previously, I could use this as `nbconvert.preprocessors.execute.CellExecutionError`.

With the current `master` version, this has changed to `nbconvert.preprocessors.CellExecutionError`.

I have nothing against the new location, but what about importing the class in the old place as well to avoid backwards-compatibility problems?

It doesn't really cost anything, does it?

items.title: PDF export incorrectly calls Inkscape for SVGs
items.body:
I tried to convert a notebook to a PDF with:

```sh
jupyter nbconvert --to pdf --TemplateExporter.exclude_input=True test.ipynb
```

And it contains SVGs like:

```json
{
   "cell_type": "code",
   "execution_count": 2,
   "metadata": {},
   "outputs": [
    {
     "data": {
      "image/svg+xml": […]
…
```

This yields following error:

```sh
Unknown option --export-pdf=/var/folders/…/figure.pdf
```

Which isn't particularly surprising, since the inkscape documentation only lists:

```txt
-o, --export-file=EXPORT-FILENAME          Output file name (file type is guessed from extension)
```

**Nbconvert version:** 5.5.0

items.title: Config option `template_path` not recognized by `NotebookExporter`.
items.body:
When I run `jupyter nbconvert --to notebook test.ipynb`, the following warning appears:

```
[NbConvertApp] WARNING | Config option `template_path` not recognized by `NotebookExporter`.
```

The notebook is still exported fine, but it would be nice to silence the warning if possible. It does not occur with any of the other export formats I tested (python, markdown, pdf, slides, html).

I don't think I have set `template_path` manually anywhere, grepping `~/.jupyter/` only shows a single commented out occurrence in `jupyter_notebook_config.py` (so not same as https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/issues/895):

```
150:# c.NotebookApp.extra_template_paths = []
```

Package versions:

```
nbconvert           5.6.1
notebook            6.0.3
IPython             7.12.0
jupyter_client      5.3.4
jupyter_core        4.6.3
jupyterlab          1.2.6
-----
Python 3.8.1 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jan 29 2020, 14:55:04) [GCC 7.3.0]
Linux-5.5.13-arch1-1-x86_64-with-glibc2.10
```

items.title: Error when running nbconvert from a notebook cell with `--TagRemovePreprocessor.remove_cell_tags`
items.body:
Running the following from command line works fine

```
jupyter nbconvert test.ipynb --TagRemovePreprocessor.remove_cell_tags='{"to_remove"}'
```

However, when I try to run it from a notebook code cell (with a prepended `!`) I get the following error message:

```
traitlets.traitlets.TraitError: The 'remove_cell_tags' trait of a TagRemovePreprocessor instance must be a set, but a value of class 'str' (i.e. 'to_remove') was specified.
```

I have tried enabling the `TagRemovePreprocessor` and change the quoting/escaping as [suggested on SO](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52834910/remove-cells-from-jupyter-notebook-with-nbconvert?noredirect=1), but the error remains.

I can't figure out how to pass a set since it is always converted to a string. Is this a bug, or is there anything I can do to fix it on my end?

Package versions:

```
nbconvert           5.6.1
notebook            6.0.3
IPython             7.12.0
jupyter_client      5.3.4
jupyter_core        4.6.3

items.title: Conversion of notebook to latex and pdf renders markdown font monospaced after display of sympy symbol
items.body:
# Description

The attached notebook `sympy.ipynb` demonstrates that the rendering of the
markdown text in pdf files created with `jupyter-nbconvert --to pdf sympy.ipynb`
is always as a monospaced font, _after_ a symbolic variable from sympy has been
displayed as a value in the notebook. (In LaTeX terms, the markdown shows up in
the tt-font.)

In the attached example, the problem starts to occur after cell `[3]`. It
remains monospaced for subsequent output cells. Note that this is also true for
the markdown after cell `[6]`.

Attached is a notebook file (original filename for the description here is
`sympy.ipynb`) which produces the pdf file, which is shown in the screen shot.

![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4489119/77818216-fe4a1d80-70d0-11ea-9b26-1d3c35ed6d68.png)

**How to reproduce**
- start from new python 3 (conda) environment
- pip install nbconvert 
- jupyter-nbconvert --to pdf sympy.ipynb

The resulting `sympy.pdf` shows the issues as described above (see ``screenshot.png`)

**Nbconvert version:**
```$ jupyter-nbconvert --version
5.6.1
```
(installed via pip on 28 March 2020


**Additional observation, LaTeX file**

When generating a LaTeX file (`jupyter-nbconvert --to latex sympy.ipynb`), and
then creating a pdf from the latex file (`pdflatex sympy.tex`), then the output
shows the same issue. 

I also attach the `sympy.tex` file, so people can look into this. Here are two sections of the file:

1. Snippet with Correctly rendered markdown output:
   ```
               \begin{tcolorbox}[breakable, size=fbox, boxrule=.5pt, pad at break*=1mm, opacityfill=0]
   \prompt{Out}{outcolor}{2}{\boxspacing}
   \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
   sympy.core.symbol.Symbol
   \end{Verbatim}
   \end{tcolorbox}
           
       Markdown is rendered normally.
   
       Once we display a symbolic variable, \ldots{}
   
   ```

2. Snippet with incorrectly rendered markdown output:
   ```
       \begin{tcolorbox}[breakable, size=fbox, boxrule=1pt, pad at break*=1mm,colback=cellbackground, colframe=cellborder]
   \prompt{In}{incolor}{3}{\boxspacing}
   \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
   \PY{n}{x}
   \end{Verbatim}
   \end{tcolorbox}
    
               
   \prompt{Out}{outcolor}{3}{}
       
       $\displaystyle x$
   
       
   
       \ldots{} subsequent markdown is rendered as monospaced font.
   
   
   ```


Versions of other software:

```
$ pdflatex --version 
pdfTeX 3.14159265-2.6-1.40.20 (TeX Live 2019)
kpathsea version 6.3.1
Copyright 2019 Han The Thanh (pdfTeX) et al.
There is NO warranty.  Redistribution of this software is
covered by the terms of both the pdfTeX copyright and
the Lesser GNU General Public License.
For more information about these matters, see the file
named COPYING and the pdfTeX source.

Compiled with libpng 1.6.36; using libpng 1.6.36
Compiled with zlib 1.2.11; using zlib 1.2.11
Compiled with xpdf version 4.01

$ pandoc --version 
pandoc 2.2.3.2
Compiled with pandoc-types 1.17.5.1, texmath 0.11.0.1, skylighting 0.7.2
Default user data directory: /Users/fangohr/.pandoc
Copyright (C) 2006-2018 John MacFarlane
Web:  http://pandoc.org
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.
There is no warranty, not even for merchantability or fitness
for a particular purpose.

$ python --version
Python 3.8.2
```

items.title: Python 3.9: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'xml.etree.cElementTree'
items.body:
**Nbconvert version:** 5.6.0 but also master

When we rebuild the nbconver package in Fedora with Python 3.9.0a5, the following tracebacks is shown:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sphinx/config.py", line 361, in eval_config_file
    execfile_(filename, namespace)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sphinx/util/pycompat.py", line 81, in execfile_
    exec(code, _globals)
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/nbconvert-5.6.0/docs/source/conf.py", line 25, in <module>
    exec(compile(f.read(), 'autogen_config.py', 'exec'), {})
  File "autogen_config.py", line 11, in <module>
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/nbconvert-5.6.0/nbconvert/__init__.py", line 4, in <module>
    from .exporters import *
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/nbconvert-5.6.0/nbconvert/exporters/__init__.py", line 3, in <module>
    from .html import HTMLExporter
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/nbconvert-5.6.0/nbconvert/exporters/html.py", line 14, in <module>
    from nbconvert.filters.highlight import Highlight2HTML
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/nbconvert-5.6.0/nbconvert/filters/__init__.py", line 7, in <module>
    from .strings import *
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/nbconvert-5.6.0/nbconvert/filters/strings.py", line 22, in <module>
    from defusedxml import cElementTree as ElementTree
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/site-packages/defusedxml/cElementTree.py", line 10, in <module>
    from xml.etree.cElementTree import TreeBuilder as _TreeBuilder
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'xml.etree.cElementTree'
```

Dependent packages also fail.

See https://docs.python.org/3.9/whatsnew/3.9.html#removed

> The xml.etree.cElementTree module has been removed.

I believe this:

https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/blob/275f7f909a803560e2459642a539874113fba959/nbconvert/filters/strings.py#L22-L23

Should be replaced to use ElementTree instead of cElementTree. I will also contact @tiran about the problem in defusedxml.

items.title: Interact widget state not stored correctly
items.body:
On notebook execution, it seems that the widget state is not embedded recursively. Only the top-level widget state is embedded. If the widget is e.g. a `VBox` consisting of several children, none of the children's state is embedded.

The issue can be reproduced by running the following command (`nbconvert 6.0.0a1.dev0`):
```
jupyter nbconvert --execute ipywidgets.ipynb --ExecutePreprocessor.store_widget_state=True --to notebook
```

On the following `ipywidgets.ipynb` notebook:
```python
from ipywidgets import interact
def f(x):
    return x
interact(f, x=10)
```

items.title: svg to pdf with Inkscape 1.0
items.body:
As of macOS Catalina (10.15), 32-bit apps are no longer allowed, so Inkscape users are forced to use Inkscape 1.0, which is currently still in beta.

There are 2 changes that are relevant to `nbconvert` to work with Inkscape 1.0:

- `--export-pdf` should be changed to `--export-file`
- The binary is now located in '/Applications/Inkscape.app/Contents/MacOS/inkscape'

I fixed the code on my local machine, but I'm not sure how to write it such that it works for both Inkscape 0.x users and 1.0 users (and for mac users and non-mac users), so perhaps someone can take a look at this.

Much appreciated!

items.title: Release
items.body: When do you plan to make a release? We need one in order to have async execution in Voila (https://github.com/voila-dashboards/voila/pull/541).

items.title: Preserve Markdown hyperlink text in Latex output
items.body:
I have notebooks with internal links that look something like this:

```markdown
# Data Analysis Methods

See the section on [Benchmarking](#Benchmarking) for more examples.

...

# Benchmarking

The methods discussed in [Data Analysis Methods](#Data-Analysis-Methods) are benchmarked in this section.

```

When I convert that to a PDF, the text I provided for the link text is omitted and replaced by "Section 1" or "Section 2.1.3" for example:

# Data Analysis Methods

See the section on [Section 2](#Benchmarking) for more examples.

...

# Benchmarking

The methods discussed in [Section 1](#Data-Analysis-Methods) are benchmarked in this section.

For my real example I have this markdown:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2966015/75390844-a2f8f580-58ae-11ea-8672-a5bbd4aadec7.png)

I see this in the HTML output:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2966015/75390794-8492fa00-58ae-11ea-9b33-176159e6f89d.png)

And this in the PDF output:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2966015/75390816-907ebc00-58ae-11ea-8f1a-bc75366a7018.png)


It looks like [this code](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/blob/9dcc8435c789954727b189bc4622e59d34f7fc07/nbconvert/filters/filter_links.py#L35
) is adding the "Section" part explicitly with a RawInline.

I wonder if there isn't a better solution that preserves the Markdown behavior so the the resulting PDF looks similar to the HTML output.

items.title: Output widgets do not render in the correct places
items.body:
<!--- Description --->
`ipywidgets.Output` objects seem to be emitted at the top level, not in their appropriate container.

<!--- Can you list steps to reproduce this issue? --->
A simple example is:

```python
import ipywidgets

vals = [1, 2, 3]
outputs = [
    ipywidgets.Output(layout=ipywidgets.Layout(flex='1'))
    for i in range(vals)
]
grid = ipywidgets.HBox(outputs)
for output, val in zip(outputs, vals):
    with output:
        print("val = {}".format(val))
grid
```

Filing after discovering this stackoverflow question: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57285733

items.title: Display interactive Vega-Lite charts in HTML output -- instead of static PNG
items.body:
I hope this is the right place to continue this discusion. https://github.com/altair-viz/altair/issues/329

Currently, NBConvert includes static PNG images in the HTML output, if the notebook includes interactive Vega-Lite charts. This is unfortunate, as interactive Vega Lite charts have a lot of added value.

As of Altair 4.0, the default renderer for Vega-Lite is HTML-based. This allows for creating HTML output with interactive Vega-Lite charts.

Questions:

- How can this functionality be included in NBConvert?
- Is there any workaround available that we could use right now?

Example code using the [Altair Chart Save API](https://altair-viz.github.io/user_guide/generated/toplevel/altair.Chart.html#altair.Chart.save).

```python
import pandas as pd
import altair as alt
from vega_datasets import data
cars = data.cars()

cars = alt.Chart(cars).mark_point().encode(
    x='Horsepower',
    y='Miles_per_Gallon',
    color='Origin',
    tooltip=['Name', 'Origin']
).interactive()

cars.save('cars.html')
```

```

Related to https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/3629, but I did not see any changes when trying the proposed work-arounds of updating nbconvert or setting it to `5.4.1`.

<!--- Can you list steps to reproduce this issue? --->

I am using [pyenv](https://github.com/pyenv/pyenv) to manage python installs, which may be correlated with this issue (in which case, maybe this issue belongs on their issue tracker). I am on OS X 10.14.

pyenv install 3.7.4 # CPython 3.7.4

python -m pip install jupyter # includes nbconvert 5.6.1
python

items.title: Export to latex gives wrong math mode format

labels.name: format:LaTeX
labels.description: pertains to exporting to the LaTeX format

items.body:
I experienced a problem with the export to *latex*. Initially I tried to export to pdf but realized that the error originates from the exported *.tex* file.

Environment
- Windows 10 1809
- Miktex 2.9.7206
- Jupyter version:   
```bash
jupyter --version
jupyter core     : 4.6.1
jupyter-notebook : 6.0.2
qtconsole        : 4.5.5
ipython          : 7.9.0
ipykernel        : 5.1.3
jupyter client   : 5.3.4
jupyter lab      : 1.0.9
nbconvert        : 5.6.1
ipywidgets       : 7.5.1
nbformat         : 4.4.0
traitlets        : 4.3.3
```

Output from pdf export in the GUI (same on the command line):
```
nbconvert failed: PDF creating failed, captured latex output:
Failed to run "xelatex .\notebook.tex -quiet" command:
notebook.tex:397: Missing $ inserted
notebook.tex:398: Missing $ inserted
```

When I exported it to Latex first, the relevant line is:
```
This is some math output: \$ \Delta x= \int B\_y dz \$
```
Isn't that wrong? To me it seems like it should not have the backslashes in front of the *$*. So when I remove the backslashes to: `This is some math output: $ \Delta x= \int B_y dz $` it compiles to pdf properly. Am I doing wrong something in the export step? Do I have an old version? I was looking for a similar issue but could not find one. Most of the other pdf export error are also related to MikTex but I think this one is more related to nbconvert isn't it? I also updated the miktex packages.

I'm thankful for any help!

items.title: nbconvert failed: [Errno 13] Permission denied
items.body:
I've been trying to figure out the root cause of this for a while, but I can't see what's wrong with our config. When trying to export a notebook as PDF from JupyterLab I am getting a permission denied error:

```
[userA@host1 ~]$ jupyter nbconvert --to pdf Untitled.ipynb
(...)
PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/latex/article.tplx'
```

`/software/jupyterhub` is where we deployed JupyterLab and `share/jupyter` is in the data path, but I don't understand why `~/.local/share/jupyter` isn't tried first:

```
[userA@host1 ~]$ jupyter --path
config:
    /home/userA/.jupyter
    /software/jupyterhub/etc/jupyter
    /usr/local/etc/jupyter
    /etc/jupyter
data:
    /home/userA/.local/share/jupyter
    /software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter
    /usr/local/share/jupyter
    /usr/share/jupyter
runtime:
    /home/userA/.local/share/jupyter/runtime

[userA@host1 software]$ jupyter --data-dir
/home/userA/.local/share/jupyter
```

If `/software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter` exists and is writeable to `userA`, the directories `nbconvert/templates/latex` get created and the conversion works (but only for `userA`):

```
[userA@host1 ~]$ ls -l /software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter/
total 152
drwxr-sr-x. 13 swuser  common 301 Jan 13 12:48 kernels
drwxr-sr-x.  8 swuser  common 181 Jan 10 14:25 lab
drwxr-sr-x.  4 swuser  common  62 Jan 13 09:47 nbextensions

[userA@host1 ~]$ touch /software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter/test_rw

[userA@host1 ~]$ jupyter nbconvert --to pdf Untitled.ipynb
[NbConvertApp] Converting notebook Untitled.ipynb to pdf
(...)
[NbConvertApp] PDF successfully created
[NbConvertApp] Writing 28002 bytes to Untitled.pdf

[userA@host1 ~]$ ls -l /software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter/
total 152
drwxr-sr-x. 13 swuser  common 301 Jan 13 12:48 kernels
drwxr-sr-x.  8 swuser  common 181 Jan 10 14:25 lab
drwxrwsr-x.  3 userA   common  27 Jan 14 15:17 nbconvert
drwxr-sr-x.  4 swuser  common  62 Jan 13 09:47 nbextensions
-rw-rw-r--.  1 userA   common   0 Jan 14 15:18 test_rw

[userA@host1 ~]$ ls -lR /software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter/nbconvert/
/software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter/nbconvert/:
total 32
drwxrwsr-x. 3 userA  common 23 Jan 14 15:17 templates

/software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates:
total 32
drwx--S---. 2 userA  common 0 Jan 14 15:17 latex

/software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter/nbconvert/templates/latex:
total 0
```

If `/software/jupyterhub/share/jupyter` is NOT writeable to `userA`, nbconvert works for all users as expected.

Any ideas?

items.title: convert notebook with html file embedded (not referenced to a local file)
items.body:
Hello,

Apologies for not being able to piece this together from what I think is a [related post](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/issues/328).

I have a [Folium](https://python-visualization.github.io/folium/) map which is saved as a standalone HTML file. I can display this map inside of a jupyter notebook by doing the following:

```python
IFrame(src='my_map.html', width=900, height=600)
```
Of course the map is a locally referenced file and so when I export this notebook and view it from another path (or on a remote server), the map is not found/is not displayed.

Is there a recommended way of embedding the HTML so that everything is contained inside the single exported notebook?

I have tried various things with nbconvert, for example:
```
jupyter nbconvert --to html --EmbedImagesPreprocessor.embed_images=True my_notebook.ipynb
```

I have also tried reading the HTML file into my notebook as a string. I figured I could use the notebook to render the string as HTML (and therefore everything would be self contained). This almost works as the interactive map appears; however, it is narrow (as shown below) and disappears completely when exported.

![sc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4624246/72288931-18b74380-3618-11ea-98e7-e2029c69a327.png)

Any help is much appreciated. If necessary I can always build the interactive maps directly in this notebook and therefore avoid linked/referenced files altogether.

Allan

items.title: What to determine failure of cell execution: error iopub message or execute_reply with error status
items.body:
There has been some discussions in the context of papermill what should be used to determine the failure of cell execution (https://github.com/nteract/papermill/issues/337), which referred to the following trunk of code

https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/blob/b31a5af48ee159f579c021b897727374f28a0800/nbconvert/preprocessors/execute.py#L475-L479 

That is to say, nbconvert considers a cell to be failed if a kernel sends an `error` message through `ioPub`, **OR** if the kernel returns `execute_reply` with a `status` of `error`. In the meantime, papermill only uses `error` message, not `execute_reply` (https://github.com/nteract/papermill/blob/0ee0da7fe7a9e8a8334011e1b1606fa86bd0ed8e/papermill/preprocess.py#L58).

I believe `execute_reply` should be the only message used because this is how Jupyter behaves with "Run all cells". That is to say, papermill should stop if a kernel sends an `execute_reply` with `error` status (but without an `error` message, https://github.com/nteract/papermill/issues/337) , and neither papermill nor nbconvert should stop if a kernel sends an `error` message, and an `execute_reply` message with `ok` status. My argument for the latter is that a kernel might want to sends an `error` message to **demonstrates or document an error** and still returns an `execute_reply` with an `ok` status so that the document could be executed successfully in batch mode.

items.title: LaTeX output cell breaks markdown rendering in LaTeX/PDF

labels.name: format:LaTeX
labels.description: pertains to exporting to the LaTeX format

items.body:
When a code cell outputs LaTeX, all following markdown cells will use typewriter font.

An [example notebook](https://gist.github.com/mstimberg/d6087a0e7f0cd4611f309780d98a48f6) renders like this in PDF:

![screenshot_nbconvert_latex_issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1381982/70793981-e4443380-1d9c-11ea-9e47-a194f3109bb9.png)

Note that the markdown cell after the code output uses a typewriter font, even though the markdown code does not ask for it.

The example uses the `sympy` package to generate LaTeX output, but any other package generating LaTeX output should be fine (using `IPython.display.display_latex` directly will generate a cell of a different type and therefore not show the issue).

From looking at the LaTeX code, the issue seems that for non-latex output, the `\prompt` command displaying the `[1]` is wrapped in a `tcolorbox` environment, whereas for latex output it isn't. Since `\prompt` switches the font to `\ttfamily`, this affects all the following text not explicitly setting a font.

This was tested in a Python 3.8 conda environment, but with using `pip install -e '.[all]'` in the master branch of `nbconvert`.

**Nbconvert version:** 6.0.0a0.dev0

items.title: Please remove package 'grffile' from latex/base.tplx - it breaks with XeLaTeX

labels.name: format:LaTeX
labels.description: pertains to exporting to the LaTeX format

items.body:
Hi, 

Dear Maintainer,

Please remove the lines

    \usepackage{grffile} % extends the file name processing of package graphics
                         % to support a larger range
    \makeatletter % fix for grffile with XeLaTeX
    \def\Gread@@xetex#1{%
      \IfFileExists{"\Gin@base".bb}%
      {\Gread@eps{\Gin@base.bb}}%
      {\Gread@@xetex@aux#1}%
    }
    \makeatother

from

    nbconvert/templates/latex/base.tplx

Even though upstream tried to fix it, grffile is broken (latest version
on github https://github.com/ho-tex/grffile is a stub).  The result is,
that notebooks exported to LaTeX or PDF will show _no_ images unless
one tells, e.g., matplotlib _explicitly_ to generate PDFs

    %matplotlib inline
    try:
        from IPython.display import set_matplotlib_formats
         set_matplotlib_formats('png','pdf')
    except Exception as e:
        pass

The attached notebook illustrates the problem.  Simply load and do **File->Export...->PDF** and one get the result shown in attachment _Bug-nofix.pdf_.  With `fix = True` at the top, one get _Bug-withfix.pdf_. 

**NBConvert version**: 5.6.0-1 (Debian 'sid')

Thanks.

Christian 
[Bug.ipynb.txt](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/files/3823899/Bug.ipynb.txt)
[Bug-nofix.pdf](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/files/3823902/Bug-nofix.pdf)

items.title: Can't modify data_png section with tplx template
items.body:
I posted this question on Jupyter Discourse [here](https://discourse.jupyter.org/t/help-using-custom-nbconvert-template-for-latex-figures/2520) 5 days ago, but haven't gotten a reply, so I'm posting here as well.

I’ve gone over the documentation on how to create a custom latex template for nbconvert, and I found a few good ones to work from, most notably Julius Schulz post [here](http://blog.juliusschulz.de/blog/ultimate-ipython-notebook#templates). Everything seemed to be working a couple of weeks ago, using the `![caption](path.png)` markdown syntax and a template similar to the one from his website, but now all of the figures are simply using the same default behavior, presumably from Pandoc. No matter what I put in the ((*- block data_png -*)) section, it makes no impact on the converted latex - every PNG always uses the formatting here:

```
\begin{figure}
\centering
\includegraphics{path.png}
\caption{caption}
\end{figure}
```
Assuming I’m the only one having this issue recently, can anyone help me understand what could be going on? The only way I can get the \begin{figure} block to change is to override ((*- block markdowncell -*)) or an input group higher up, but I would have thought something like
```
((*- block data_png -*))
<My LaTeX code>
((* endblock *))
```
would override Pandoc’s behavior for any PNG image and allow me to use my code instead.

Thank you!

When a notebook cell times out, nbconvert stops with an error, as expected. However, the documentation says that it should print out _the contents of the cell that had the error_, but it does not:
> Conveniently, the source cell causing the error and the original error name and message are also printed.
- https://nbconvert.readthedocs.io/en/latest/execute_api.html#execution-until-first-error

items.title: Make HTML export responsive/mobile friendly
items.body:
<!--- Is your feature request related to a problem? What are you trying to achieve? --->

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/3275

The advantage of exporting as HTML is that any widgets made using jupyter notebook/lab is are interactive. Currently exporting code as HTML is not mobile-friendly. 

One application would be in scientific presentations. Many scientists make plots that are interactive instead of static. You could imagine all an audience member has to do to play with the plots is simply view the HTML file in their browser. As you might have guessed, this doesn't look very nice on mobile. This might not matter for lectures where more people have laptops ready, but for poster sessions, the only device people have on hands are usually their phones. 

<!--- Describe the solution you'd like. --->

When exporting as HTML, add support for mobile. In general, make HTML exports responsive to any browser.

<!--- If possible, describe alternatives you've considered. Why are they insufficient? --->
Currently, HTML exports are designed only for desktop browsers. Others have suggested to make Jupyter Notebook/Lab itself mobile-friendly which would be nice but might be difficult to implement.

items.title: Document or remove dependence of RegExRemove Processor on outputs
items.body:
The `RegExRemoveProcessor` removes cells if they match the given regular expression and have no output.

This is not made clear in the docstring, but feels like surprising behavior to me. I often want to remove cells based only on their contents, not on whether they have outputs, and in fact often want to remove cells that produce outputs, e.g. solution cells in an educational notebook. As it stands, without looking at the source, there is no way to know that the outputs of the cell influence this preprocessor, which makes debugging difficult. My current work-around is to use the `ClearOutputPreprocessor` first, but that won't work if I need to preserve some, but not all, outputs.

If that is expected and desired behavior, it should be noted [here, in the docstring](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/blob/2e0baa25160ebf342f798198a28ee5364ebcd4fa/nbconvert/preprocessors/regexremove.py#L20), perhaps by changing the linked line to:

```
    of unicode strings. If the contents match any of the patterns and the cell
    has no outputs, the cell is removed from the notebook.
```

But I would personally prefer the behavior in [this version](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/blame/3860a848ccfde8e86f5b278fe85177f8786c663c/nbconvert/preprocessors/regexremove.py), which simply removes cells that match, or a flag to switch between the two behaviors.

**Nbconvert version:** Any after a8cb3a5, linked above (.

Thanks for making a box of really nice tools! Couldn't effectively teach without them.

items.title: Colored Text Crashes PDF Export
items.body:
<!--- Description --->

Printing colored text results in latex conversion when exporting to pdf that fail to process by xelatex.

<!--- Can you list steps to reproduce this issue? --->

Executing and then exporting via `jupyter nbconvet --to=pdf ColorExportFail`
```
from colorama import Fore, Back, Style 
print(Fore.RED + 'red')
```

Raises an exception:
```
! FancyVerb Error:
  Empty verbatim environment
.
\FV@Error ...ncyVerb Error:^^J\space \space #1^^J}
                                                  
l.381 }\end{Verbatim}
```

Just exporting the latex via `jupyter nbconvet --to=latex ColorExportFail` produces
```
    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\textcolor{ansi-red}{red
}\end{Verbatim}
```

Instead of
```
    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\textcolor{ansi-red}{red}
\end{Verbatim}
```
The extra newline breaks exports.

<!--- Can you, if possible, please attach a minimum notebook that reproduces this issue on conversion?
You may need to attach the .ipynb as a .txt --->

[ColorExportFail.txt](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/files/3439599/ColorExportFail.txt)

<!--- Can you attach screenshots if relevant? --->

<!--- Are you running the latest version of nbconvert? --->
This is on current master (5.5.0)

items.title: nbconvert command get unexpected stdout even when not use the --stdout flag.
items.body:
<!--- Description --->
`jupyter-nbconvert` command will get unexpected stdout even when we not use `--stdout` flag.
<!--- Can you list steps to reproduce this issue? --->
Create a notebook name as `unexpect_output.ipynb` and fill out the below code.
```python
import subprocess
proc = subprocess.Popen(['date'])
proc.communicate()
proc.wait()
```
Use `jupyter-nbconvert` command line to execute it.
```bash
$ jupyter-nbconvert --to notebook --execute unexpect_output.ipynb
[NbConvertApp] Converting notebook ng-stdout.ipynb to notebook
[NbConvertApp] Executing notebook with kernel: python3
Tue Jul  9 14:29:48 JST 2019
[NbConvertApp] Writing 837 bytes to ng-stdout.nbconvert.ipynb
```
But if we put `stdout=subprocess.PIPE` into subprocess call. The will no expected stdout coming out.
<!--- Can you, if possible, please attach a minimum notebook that reproduces this issue on conversion?
You may need to attach the .ipynb as a .txt --->

<!--- Can you attach screenshots if relevant? --->

<!--- Are you running the latest version of nbconvert? --->
**Nbconvert version:** 5.4.1

It looks like if we do not use `PIPE` to connect subprocess stdout, the `jupyter-nbconvert` command will lead the output to its stdout. I think this will be an issue, as developer maybe cannot consider this situation when they use `nb-convert` as a library to write their customize notebook execution function.

items.title: allowing shebang `#!` when converting to script

labels.name: format:Script
labels.description: pertains to exporting to the script/python formats

items.body:
My first notebook cell starts with a shebang, e.g.:
```
#!/usr/bin/env julia
versioninfo()
```

When I convert this notebook to a `--to=script` the output starts with a new line followed by the she bang:

```

#!/usr/bin/env julia
versioninfo()
```

However the newline prevents the shebang to be interpreted as such. The first new line (0x0a) should be omitted.

items.title: What is the exit code of nbconvert when notebooks contain errors?
items.body:
I’m asking this question in relation to my [StackOverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56829159/azure-devops-does-not-fail-when-command-execution-fails?noredirect=1#comment100211336_56829159), where I noticed that Azure was not failing when nbconvert executes and fails to build a notebook in my repository. 

I’m just wondering, what is the exit code of nbconvert if a cell in a notebook errors out? Does it return a non-zero exit code? 

Thank you for taking the time to read, and thanks in advance for your response.

items.title: NBConvert 5.6 Release
items.body:
We have a lot of really nice features merged into nbconvert that don't need to wait for the 6.0 release. We're waiting for jupyter_client to release https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter_client/pull/438 (should be any day now) to enable parallel processing. There's still a rare race condition for ipython kernels, but https://github.com/ipython/ipykernel/pull/412 once passing should resolve the issues there. I don't want to block the release on this change.

Are there any open PRs we want merged before such a release? I will note I do not have time to finish the requested changes on https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/pull/986 for this release. I will endeavour to fix that before 6.0 if I can though.

items.title: Building documention on windows doesn't include config_option.rst
items.body:
On RTD, the ```config_options.rst``` file is generated from the conf.py. On Linux/MacOS, this is built by the makefile. On windows, this is not included in ```make.bat```. I only discovered this because I'm currently redesigning the ```config_options.rst``` page.

IMHO. This should be done from within the conf.py file on all platforms.

items.title: Kernel dying mysteriously when using ExecutePreprocessor/Exporter in docker container
items.body:
I am running ExecutePreprocessor and Exporter as part of a notebook training application, component looks something like this:

`preprocessor = ExecutePreprocessor(timeout=-1, kernel_name=self.kernel)`
`exec = Exporter()`
`exec.register_preprocessor(preprocessor, True)`
`exec.from_file(self.notebook_file)`

This runs no problem locally but when running this code in a docker image, the kernel seems to die mysteriously with a rather vague error message:

> Kernel died while waiting for execute reply.

Time-out occurs after 1 - 2 minutes so execution time is definitely not extreme.

Could be related to one of these two:
https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/issues/277
https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter_client/issues/142

nbconvert==5.5.0

items.title: Deprecated exporter_locator always imported
items.body:
exporter_locator is always imported in `export.py` while it is deprecated.

```
./export.py:from .exporter_locator import *
./exporter_locator.py:warnings.warn("""`nbconvert.exporters.exporter_locator` is deprecated in favor of `nbconvert.exporters.base` since nbconvert 5.0.""",
```

items.title: Optional store_history for ExecutePreprocessor.preprocess_cell
items.body: I would appreciate having the option to turn off history storing when calling preprocess_cell for an ExecutePreprocessor.  That is, accept an additional "store_history" argument with a default value of True in the preprocess_cell method, as well as the run_cell method.  This "store_history" would need to be passed from preprocess_cell to run_cell which will then pass it on to the "execute" method of the KernelClient object.  I would find this convenient when using nbconvert to execute a collection of notebooks for regression testing and don't have a need to store the history while doing so.  I have tested out that this suits my purposes by overriding "run_cell" and passing store_history=False to the KernelClient's "execute" method.

items.title: Backwards compatibility broken on #markdown2html()
items.body:
Compatibility with fast.ai's librarys doc() method is broken. Using it now creates an error due to the latest update in markdown2html.

Commit 654d6a395650e403b41f16a235cf29f0fdb29a92 changes the method signature:

```
- def markdown2html(self, source):
+ def markdown2html(self, context, source):
```

fast.ai's librarys doc() method calls `output = HTMLExporter().markdown2html(md)`

Is it possible to make the change backwards compatible instead of introducing a mandatory extra argument in front of the old one?

items.title: Compatibility issue with latest reveal.js release (script error)?
items.body:
I'm trying to publish a set of converted slides using GitHub Pages and deploying via TravisCI, and I've been successful in the past doing so, this is how I'm deploying on TravisCI:

```
install:
    - pip install jupyter
    - wget https://github.com/hakimel/reveal.js/archive/master.zip
    - unzip master.zip
    - mv reveal.js-master reveal.js

script:
    - jupyter nbconvert nb.ipynb --to slides --reveal-prefix=reveal.js

after_success: |
    if [ -n "$GITHUB_API_KEY" ]; then
    git checkout --orphan gh-pages
    git rm -rf --cached .
    mv nb.slides.html index.html
    git add -f --ignore-errors index.html img reveal.js
    git -c user.name='travis' -c user.email='travis' commit -m init
    git push -f -q https://$GITHUB_USER:$GITHUB_API_KEY@github.com/$TRAVIS_REPO_SLUG gh-pages
    fi
```

However over the last 10 days the slides won't load and I keep getting the following recurring issues during deployment:

```
Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 ()  
/deploy/custom.css:1 

Uncaught Error: Load timeout for modules: reveal.js/lib/js/head.min.js,reveal.js/js/reveal.js
http://requirejs.org/docs/errors.html#timeout
    at C (require.min.js:8)
    at D (require.min.js:13)
    at require.min.js:14

Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 ()
head.min.js:1

require.min.js:8 Uncaught Error: Script error for: reveal.js/lib/js/head.min.js
http://requirejs.org/docs/errors.html#scripterror
    at C (require.min.js:8)
    at HTMLScriptElement.onScriptError (require.min.js:29)
```

I am still able to deploy the slides locally, and they look as they should:
`jupyter nbconvert *.ipynb --to slides --post serve`

[According to Hakim](https://github.com/hakimel/reveal.js/issues/2382), `head.min.js` was removed from the latest reveal.js release. But I noticed that `head.min.js` is inserted into the html files of both the converted notebook slides and the index of the reveal.js submodule. Thus are the script errors the result of compatibility between reveal.js and nbconverter? What can I do to deploy the slides normally?

items.title: html dedent for markdown export
items.body:
nbconvert doesn't dedent 'text/html' outputs, which leads to errors down the line (specifically when converting notebooks that use plotly to Markdown).

To exemplify this issue, convert any notebook that uses plotly to markdown and you'll see the plotly js code (that came from a text/html output cell output -- but was indented) is displayed as verbatim rather than executed.
Given that HTML is dedent invariant (that was awkward to write) it seems like the reader should dedent by default?

I started digging into the code, but wasn't sure where would be the best place to add this. Is this something you all would be into? I can write a pull request, I just need to know where would be a sane place for it?

items.title: tornado >= 6 dependency breaks nbconvert behavior
items.body:
Looks like `tornado >= 6` has some breaking changes. Reproducible on Windows and OSX, I have `nbconvert==5.4.0` and `tornado==6.0.2`. [Full conda env can be viewed here](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/files/3039941/full_conda_env_nbconvert_bug.txt)


```bash
(geosaurus_dev_env) ~ $ jupyter nbconvert ./Untitled.ipynb

    class ProxyHandler(web.RequestHandler):
  File "/Users/davi9349/anaconda3/envs/geosaurus_dev_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/nbconvert/postprocessors/serve.py", line 21, in ProxyHandler

AttributeError: module 'tornado.web' has no attribute 'asynchronous'
```

If I downgrade to a `5.X.X` of `tornado` this issue goes away.

items.title: Cells with %%time magic seem not to execute in nbconvert?
items.body: I have been using `nbconvert` along with a few other scripts for my presentations and exercises to ensure all of the cells run correctly. Recently I have noticed that a lot of my builds were failing and it appears that the cells with `%%time` magic were not being executed by nbconvert (https://circleci.com/gh/kmader/Quantitative-Big-Imaging-2019/79?utm_campaign=vcs-integration-link&utm_medium=referral&utm_source=github-build-link) and thus the appropriate variables were not being defined, simply deleting the `%%time` statements fixed the issue, but this didn't used to be an issue at all.

items.title: invalid filename for PDFExporter.latex_command

labels.name: format:PDF
labels.description: pertains to exporting to the PDF format

items.body:
Dear all,

I am not able to generate a PDF via pdflatex in Windows. The same code with the same configuration works on Ubuntu 18.04 x64 but fails on Windows 10 x64, with nbconvert 5.4.1 installed from conda-forge.

My `jupyter_nbconvert_config.py` has the following definition for latex_command:

`c.PDFExporter.latex_command = ['pdflatex', '{filename}']`

In Windows, it looks like the notebook.tex filename gets an extra backslash: 
```
[NbConvertApp] Running pdflatex 3 times: ['pdflatex', '.\\notebook.tex']

[NbConvertApp] CRITICAL | p failed: pdflatex .\notebook.tex

This is pdfTeX, Version 3.14159265-2.6-1.40.19 (TeX Live 2018/W32TeX) (preloaded format=pdflatex)

restricted \write18 enabled.

entering extended mode

! Undefined control sequence.

<*> .\notebook

              .tex

?

! Emergency stop.

<*> .\notebook

              .tex

!  ==> Fatal error occurred, no output PDF file produced!
```

Whereas it works on Linux:
`[NbConvertApp] Running pdflatex 3 times: ['pdflatex', './notebook.tex']`

Thank you,
Cheers
GorgiAstro

items.title: PDFExporter needs to have output_mimetype attribute set
items.body:
The [notebook](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/blob/b26221ad44037f16610db0234ef109d7879ab437/notebook/nbconvert/handlers.py#L182) uses this attribute as the `Content-Type` header, and currently this is being picked up from its superclass, ``LatexExporter`` - [here](https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/blob/0ef92837822da09821b96955074002726b08a99f/nbconvert/exporters/latex.py#L46).

Let me know if you have any issues if I set this to ``application/pdf`` in the subclass

items.title: output saved partially to the notebook when executing with timeout=-1
items.body:
I executed a notebook with nbconvert command and the notebook takes a long time to be fully executed. It finishes successfully executing. However the output is partially written in the new notebook. Is there any way to write the output to the files during execution?


Note: I was trying to save the output in the same file with --inplace=True.

items.title: Feature request: custom output filename
items.body:
Current command:
```
jupyter nbconvert --to script "10.3.19 some complicated filename I use for explaining to my clients.ipynb"

# output : creates "10.3.19 some complicated filename I use for explaining to my clients.py"
```

Desired command:
```
jupyter nbconvert --to script --o "run1.py" "10.3.19 some complicated filename I use for explaining to my clients.ipynb"
# output : creates "run1.py"
```
Possible?

items.title: Great! You will need to add handling of [input requests](http://jupyter-client.readthedocs.org/en/latest/messaging.html#messages-on-the-stdin-router-dealer-sockets) on the input channel of the KernelClient. you will also want to add `allow_stdin=True` to the execute requests, to enable these messages.
items.body:
Great! You will need to add handling of [input requests](http://jupyter-client.readthedocs.org/en/latest/messaging.html#messages-on-the-stdin-router-dealer-sockets) on the input channel of the KernelClient. you will also want to add `allow_stdin=True` to the execute requests, to enable these messages.

_Originally posted by @minrk in https://github.com/jupyter/nbconvert/issues/288#issuecomment-208331975_
